intro: Diodia cymosa var. aculeolata, commonly known as the hairy diodia, is a flowering plant native to the southern United States. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its small, white to pale yellow flowers. The plant typically grows in dry, sandy soils and is often found in open woodlands or along roadsides. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, giving it a rough texture. The variety aculeolata is distinguished by its more pronounced hairy structures, particularly on the stems and leaves.
